elements.text: [Part One]
The Tardis materialises, scanner activates.
And that’s where this message is coming from. That asteroid. A lonely looking hunk of nothing much.
Oh. I thought you were taking us straight there, to the source of the message.
Not yet, Mel. I thought best be on the safe side.
Mmm, you’re worried, aren’t you?
Well, let’s just say my reckless days are long over. I want to hear what this message actually says first.
It doesn’t look very promising. I’m not keen on floating chunks of space waste. I mean, look at it. It’s like an old skull or something.
Mmm, well, appearances can be deceptive.
Beeping.
Ah ha. There we are. You were right to be wary.
Don't tell me. Severe radiation warning?
Very severe. Looks lethal.
Let me see those readings. Oh, decidedly nasty, I’d say.
We'd have been burned to a frazzle.
Or worse.
What’s worse than a frazzle? Hey, the readings are fluctuating. Can they do that?
I don’t know. It’s very strange.
You know, I really don’t like the look of that rock.
And they do say discretion is the better part of valour.
You mean we could just go somewhere else and forget about it?
Yes. It probably isn’t anything vital.
Aren’t you curious, though?

I can’t deny that. I can’t deny that the moment we received the transmission... I don’t know. I felt... something. Something inexplicable. But curiosity and cats don’t always mix well, and I’m feeling distinctly feline today.
Crackle on intercom.
Wait a minute. Something’s coming through. Well, I never. And who do you think they are?

[OC]: We have waited such a long time to welcome you to our home. It will be a great honour for the two of us to receive you here at our humble abode. Please do not be put off by our apparently hostile environment, or the seemingly noxious atmosphere in which we exist. We have survived here and are sure you will be able to do so as well. Welcome, O thrice welcome, my friends. We are eager to make your acquaintance. Are we not, Eliza?
[OC]: Who? What? Yes, yes, oh yes, we are, we are.
[OC]: My name is Maria Applewhite and this is my sister Eliza. Say hello, Eliza.
[OC]: Hello, out there. Greetings (heavy static) Hello.
[OC]: Forgive my sister. She’s so keen though, so anxious to meet with you, she’s (heavy static) welcome you too, to give you your dearest wish, just as you deserve.
[OC]: Oh yes, yes indeed.
Is that it?
Oh. Well, they seemed like very pleasant old ladies.
Were they talking to us directly, or was it just some pre-recorded general message?
It found us, didn’t it? Let’s try it again.
Doctor, look.
Hmm? Something wrong?
Look, the readings. Everything’s changed.
Safe radiation levels? Breathable atmosphere?
But how can it suddenly have changed?
Signs of civilisation! Vegetation, small settlement nearby, a large house in the woods.
That’s where they live?
Seems to be.
So we’ve changed our minds? We’re going to land.
They seem friendly enough. They invited us to pay a visit. And I am rather intrigued by an environment that can completely change itself seemingly at will.
The Tardis dematerialises.
My dear, my dear, you must wake. See what today has brought us
What? What? What?
There is an arrival, my dear. A new arrival. Perhaps the one we have waited for.
Who? Who did you say was here?
They have come. I just know they have. We have guests, Eliza.
A long time since the last ones.
I know.
Quickly, help me. Unburnish my eyes, find my glasses. Help me, hmm? Help me up to face the day.
A tawny owl hoots. The Tardis door opens.
Oh, it’s cold, isn’t it?
Tardis door closes.
It’s a pity your leg warmers don’t reach all the way up to your neck, isn’t it? Seriously, though, do you want to nip back into the Tardis and get that winter coat of yours?
No, it’s all right. Look, there’s the house. Not too far away, is it?
Well, if you’re sure.
It’s incredible. It really does look like something from Earth.
Rather Gaudi-esque, all those blobby organic bits and the funny windows. Mel?
I still don’t get it. None of this was here, was it?
Perhaps none of this appeared to be here because someone didn’t want us to see it yet. Perhaps they wanted to check us out first.
Those old ladies?
Could be.
Yes, well, can we go and announce ourselves, Doctor? I’m not sure I like it out here. I feel like there’s something watching us.
Actually, so do I.
A twig breaks.
I didn’t imagine that, did 1?
Er, no. And it sounds like it’s between us and the Tardis. It’s probably nothing.
Probably nothing. Are you sure?
Er, well, no. So just in case, let’s head straight for the house at er, well, a brisk pace.
Okay. I mean, it isn’t far, is it? We could er... we could go a bit faster, if you liked.
Mmm, yeah.
Doctor?
Good idea. And hold my hand, would you?
Are you that scared?
Weird noise.
Perhaps we should, you know, run! Run, Mel. Don’t look back.
Come. Come back. Come back. We don’t want to hurt you. Stay here in the woods. Stay here with us. The Applewhite house won’t save you. There’s no protection there for you.
Knocking on door.
Hello? Are you in?
We got your message.
Hello!
Maybe it was just a recording, and those poor old dears are long dead.
Door being unlocked.
Ah, or maybe they’re still alive.
Door opens.
My dears, you are here.
We picked up your message. It took some decoding, but I made sense of it in the end.
Hello, I’m Melanie, and this is the Doctor.
I take it that it was us you were wanting to see?
Ah, Melanie, Doctor. What a sight for sore eyes, eh, Eliza?
Sore eyes. Sore eyes. So bright. I have sore eyes.
I didn’t mean your eyes, my dear. I meant our guests. How pleased we are to see them, are we not?
Oh, we are, we are.
Come in.
Door closes.
Oh, that’s much better. Much warmer in here.
Let me take your coats. You have come far?
Well, impossibly far, you could say.
How marvellous.
What do you reckon? Harmless?
Mostly, it would seem.
I can’t tell you how delighted and amazed we are that you would listen to our message, and respond like you have.
[OC]: Bring them in here, by the fire.
Er, how long is it exactly since you sent your message out? I don’t mean to be, well, indelicate, but you do appear to be a little — how can I put it?
Older?
Oh shush, Mel.
Oh, don’t worry, Doctor. Melanie is right. Yes, it has been many years since we recorded our message, and it has been a long time since anyone last came here.
Such a long time. A long, long, long time.
And you need our help.
Of course, of course. Help! Help!
Don’t mind my sister. She’s agitated. She will calm down soon. Will you take tea, or sherry?
Whichever you prefer, ladies.
Then it shall be sherry. Sherry for the great hero from beyond Space and Time.
Oh, well, you know, modesty forbids and all that.
Eliza dear, you will have the honour of serving our guests, if you don’t mind.
My pleasure. My pleasure.
Please, don’t go to any trouble.
Yes, we were more than happy to respond to your call.
Quite. We have cakes also.
Your sister. Can she manage all right, serving us?
Whatever does he mean, manage? Milk for both of you?
In the sherry?
Forgive me, madam, but the dark glasses, I thought perhaps that your sister was...
We have lived here a long time, Doctor. She knows her way around. But yes, her sight was lost many years ago, when we first arrived.
The burning, the brightness! Aieee! My eyeballs simply melted in their sockets. One lump or two?
Er, no sugar for me.
Sweet or dry sherry, Doctor?
Oh, I see. Dry, please. I’m sorry to hear about your accident.
Crash.
Bother.
Our arrival on this world was rather violent, unexpected.
Cursed. It was cursed, and so are we. Here we are. Refreshments.
Oh, marvellous. Now, I’m afraid we couldn’t quite make out some parts of your message, so I was wondering if you could tell us
The Wishing Beast.
Wishing?
Beast?
That is what we have brought you here to see.
Ah. I see. Or rather, I’m afraid I don’t.
The Wishing Beast doesn’t mean any harm, and he has called out to the hero of Space and Time in order to bestow a reward.
A reward? What kind of reward?
The hero’s dearest wish, of course.
Really. Well, that’s very kind of you.
Sounds a bit like something out of a fairy tale.
Yes, well, it’s very kind of you to offer me my dearest wish, ladies, but I’m not sure
You, Doctor? You assume the reward is for you?
Oh, er, well, I suppose I did, rather, yes.
But we intended that the Wishing Beast should give the just reward to the brave explorer and great hero of Time and Space.
Er, well, yes?
Why Melanie, it is you who the Wishing Beast wants to see.
Mel spits out her drink and starts coughing.
You are the reason we sent out our message.
Me?
Well, lucky old you, Mel.
Kettle boiling.
Such a lovely girl, isn’t she, Eliza? So natural. So modest, too. Did you hear the surprise in her voice when we told her?
Modest. Modesty becomes her. Not the Doctor.
Oh no. The poor Doctor was bamboozled, wasn’t he? I shouldn’t laugh, but his expression was a picture, wasn't it?
A picture. Picture. A picture of what, though?
What indeed. But I must get back to them. I'll leave you to make that fresh pot of tea, my dear. Now, are these cakes ready to go?
Take them. Take them cakes.
Well, this is all very strange, isn’t it?
Oh, come on, don’t pretend you’re not a bit put out.
Put out? What, that I’m not the great hero of Space and Time?
But you are though, aren’t you.
What, the great hero of Space and Time, or put out?
Both.
So, given any thought what your dearest wish might be, Princess Mel?
I think they’re both a bit doolally, don’t you? I mean, perhaps I should graciously decline and offer you up in my place.
Well, let’s just play along for the time being. I want to find out what’s
Shh. They're coming back.
Door opens.
My sister will be here with more tea presently. Would you like some more sherry, Doctor?
Well, that’s very kind of you, Maria, but I won't, thank you.
Moaning sound, Eliza whimpering, glass breaks. Door opens.
Eliza, what have you done?
Stupid, stupid Eliza. I dropped them, Maria. I dropped the lot! Look, spilled and smashed. No good, no good now.
It’s all right. It doesn’t matter.
Here, let me help.
What made you drop them? We heard something.
It was the noise, Maria. Those... those things are getting in.
Things?
Getting in from outside. They’re coming in from the woods. They are coming into our house now. We must be on our guard.
What things, Eliza?
Ghostly ghosts.
She hears things. The noises play havoc with her imagination.
Ghosts? Are you sure, Eliza?
Oh yes. I heard them. Nasty things. Fading away things. Even with my poor eyes I can glimpse them, shimmering, silvery, at the corner of my vision, the little I have left to me.
Calm down, my dear. Calm down. Come and sit down.
There’s no such thing as ghosts, Eliza. You’re safe.
But there is. Here on this world there is... something. This last remaining shard of a world, this awful splinter.
Really?
Awful splinter?
Door opens, Doctor straining.
Here, help me settle her on the sofa.
One, two, three, hup. Ah. There, better now?
Much.
Tell us more, Maria, about the ghosts.
The woods, out there, they are alive with ghosts, with macabre presences. We are safe here indoors, except lately my sister has been sensing them in here.
They are getting inside. They are all around us.
Oh, it is of no interest to you. We mustn’t be side-tracked into talking about our fears and our woes.
Oh, we don’t mind, do we, Doctor?
Of course not.
We’d like to help if we can.
Another sherry, Doctor. Let us listen to Melanie. Melanie, will you tell us about your adventures in Time and Space?
Oh, really, it’s not just me
Actually, I won’t have another drink, thank you. I think I'll pop back to the Tardis. I want to, well, check she’s safely locked up. I don’t want ghosts creeping around inside it.
Oh, ghosts inside.
There, there, there. There, there, there.
(sotto) Do you really think they might get inside?
Probably not, but I want to see if the Tardis has picked up any psionic energy emissions.
Psionic? But what about me?
Oh, I think these two are harmless enough. (normal) So, you carry on, Mel. You stay here. Tell them about your travels.
All right, Doctor.
Stay, Doctor. Stay here by the fire.
No, really, I need to stretch my legs.
Oh, of course. You are our honoured guest. The companion of Melanie. You must come and go as you please.
You're very kind.
A clock chimes.
Dinner will be at six, Doctor.
Splendid. Just enough time. Ladies.
More, Melanie. Tell us more.
Yes, tell us all about your fabulous adventures.
Let’s see what kind of energy emissions we’re getting. Ah. Most interesting. You’re out there, aren’t you. I can sense you. The Tardis can feel your presence. Make yourself known to me.
Tapping.
So you are there. Almost intangible, almost invisible, but you are there. You’re trying to get through, you’re trying to communicate. Is it me you want? Are you trying to talk to me, hmm?
Banging on door.
Tell me, I'll listen. Talk to me. (silence) Oh, come back. What’s happened to you? Come back and talk to me! Ah, gone. Energy emissions have gone too. But it was definitely there.
Ah. Really, I must say compliments to the chef, Maria. The food is excellent.
It really is.
Daniel would have been so pleased to meet them, wouldn’t he, Eliza?
Oh yes. Yes, oh yes.

He so wanted to be a traveller himself, you see. Why, he would have been flabbergasted by your tales of travelling the cosmos. The way you make it sound, it seems so easy. Skipping from world to world, time after time.
So easy. Too easy.
Well, it’s not as easy as all that. But tell me, who is Daniel?
Daniel is... Daniel is no more. Daniel was. He was once.

Shush. Eliza, don’t upset yourself. Daniel was our brother, Melanie. He died many years ago. When we first came to this terrible land it was just the three of us. Like three shipwrecked sailors we were, washed up on the jagged reefs of this asteroid. We were only children. Just little children.
Daniel was our brother. He was younger than us, but he was our champion, our protector. He was, he was.
Oh, I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to pry
Well, we all have our sad tales, don’t we.
Do you, Doctor?
Oh, enough of this gloomy talk. What about this Wishing Beast, hmm? I’m fascinated by that.
Tomorrow. Tomorrow is the day for wishes.
My sister is correct. Tomorrow all will become clear. You will receive your reward, Melanie.
Really, you know, I don’t actually need a reward. Honestly.
Oh, don’t be so modest, Mel. Just look at the things you’ve faced up to since you’ve been in my company. Awful things.
Eliza, do come and help me with dessert. Do forgive us, Melanie. We must go and tend to the dessert.
Just desserts, eh?
I’m sorry?
Just a joke.
Ah yes. You are very whimsical, Doctor. What a boon you must be to Melanie on her adventures. Come, sister.
Door opens and closes.
Oh. Well, am I a boon?
(laughing) Oh definitely, Doctor. Wait till you see the rooms they've given us. Mine is just spectacular. Real luxury.
I’m not sure I want to stay the night here. Not after what happened when I went back to the Tardis.
Oh yes. Quick, tell me before they come back.
I was haunted.
What? Doctor, are you sure?
I was in the console room, and there was this tapping on the outer shell of the Tardis. And when I talked to it, it became louder, more frenetic.
Someone outside?
The instruments gave only a partial reading, but there was something. Someone was there, someone not quite solid, someone not quite...
Not quite what?
Not quite living.
Did you see them?
They evaporated. Simply melted away.
Do you think whoever it was was following us in the woods?
Perhaps. But there’s worse than that. The Tardis herself is somehow affected. Jammed.
Jammed?
We couldn't take off now if we wanted to. Something has got into her.
Door opens.
Here we are.
Door closes.
We are, we are. Here’s just desserts.
That’s magnificent!
That must be the biggest trifle in the universe.
You flatter us, Doctor.
And you are spoiling us, my dear Maria.
Will you let me propose a toast?
Oh, yes.
Blessings on our esteemed guests, and especially to Melanie, whose travels we have been hearing so much about.
To Melanie.
Tomorrow you will receive your great reward, Melanie.
Distant door slams.
What was that?
A door, I think.
Reward, reward. Tomorrow will be the day.
Tomorrow we rise early and we ride out deep into the woods, in our carriage.
A nearer door slams.
There, again.
But can’t they hear it?
Hear what, my dear?
Doors slamming, crashes. Mel, you can hear it too, can’t you? Don’t tell me it’s just me.
I can. It’s
Now, tomorrow we shall go searching for the Wishing Beast himself.
Excuse me, Maria, but those noises.
Noises, noises. It’s the noisy noises, Maria.
Big bang, eerie sounds.
More of your ghosts, Maria?
Please ignore them. There’s nothing to see.
Whoosh, breaking glass, moaning.
We asked you to listen. We asked you to hear us. We didn’t want to cause a scene or make a fuss. Now you will listen to us.
I don't believe it. Ghosts!
Noisy ghosts. I don’t like them. Make them go away.
Leave us! Be gone! Ignore them, everyone. Pay them no heed.
Oh my God, Doctor.
It’s all right, Mel. Don’t panic.
But that was right beside me.
Go on, Maria. Carry on with what you were saying.
Thank you, Doctor. We will all ride in our carriage to the very depths of the woods, and there we will face the Wishing Beast together, and Melanie will tell him her dearest wish.
She will. She will ask for her dearest wish.
I’m not even sure what that is.
And then, Maria?
And then, naturally, he will grant it.
How? Why?
You will see, Doctor.

Sounds suspiciously like magic to me. And magic, like ghosts, may appear to be inexplicable, but they are only unexplained. And at the moment all this looks like a pretty poor display of cheap theatrics.
I think you spoke too soon, Doctor. Look at that thing. It’s horrible.
How are you doing this, Maria? Is it you doing this?
Take it away. Take it.
It has nothing to do with us, Doctor. These things come and go at will.
Please, now we have your attention. Please, you must, you have to listen to us. Hard to cut through... psychic interference. The sisters won’t let us talk with you. We want to help
What's it saying?
Be gone. Leave us!
Be gone! Be gone! Be gone!
Quiet! Let us hear.
Doctor, Mel, listen to me. Flee from here. The sisters, they will be the death of all of us!

DOCTOR: Oh, marvellous. Now, I’m afraid we couldn’t quite make out some parts of your message, so I was wondering if you could tell us
MARIA: The Wishing Beast.
DOCTOR: Wishing?
MEL: Beast?
MARIA: That is what we have brought you here to see.
DOCTOR: Ah. I see. Or rather, I’m afraid I don’t.
MARIA: The Wishing Beast doesn’t mean any harm, and he has called out to the hero of Space and Time in order to bestow a reward.
DOCTOR: A reward? What kind of reward?
MARIA: The hero’s dearest wish, of course.
DOCTOR: Really. Well, that’s very kind of you.
MEL: Sounds a bit like something out of a fairy tale.
DOCTOR: Yes, well, it’s very kind of you to offer me my dearest wish, ladies, but I’m not sure
MARIA: You, Doctor? You assume the reward is for you?
DOCTOR: Oh, er, well, I suppose I did, rather, yes.
MARIA: But we intended that the Wishing Beast should give the just reward to the brave explorer and great hero of Time and Space.
DOCTOR: Er, well, yes?
MARIA: Why Melanie, it is you who the Wishing Beast wants to see.
MARIA: You are the reason we sent out our message.
MEL: Me?
DOCTOR: Well, lucky old you, Mel.
MARIA: Such a lovely girl, isn’t she, Eliza? So natural. So modest, too. Did you hear the surprise in her voice when we told her?
ELIZA: Modest. Modesty becomes her. Not the Doctor.
MARIA: Oh no. The poor Doctor was bamboozled, wasn’t he? I shouldn’t laugh, but his expression was a picture, wasn't it?
ELIZA: A picture. Picture. A picture of what, though?
MARIA: What indeed. But I must get back to them. I'll leave you to make that fresh pot of tea, my dear. Now, are these cakes ready to go?
ELIZA: Take them. Take them cakes.
DOCTOR: Well, this is all very strange, isn’t it?
MEL: Oh, come on, don’t pretend you’re not a bit put out.
DOCTOR: Put out? What, that I’m not the great hero of Space and Time?
MEL: But you are though, aren’t you.
DOCTOR: What, the great hero of Space and Time, or put out?
MEL: Both.
DOCTOR: So, given any thought what your dearest wish might be, Princess Mel?
MEL: I think they’re both a bit doolally, don’t you? I mean, perhaps I should graciously decline and offer you up in my place.
DOCTOR: Well, let’s just play along for the time being. I want to find out what’s
MEL: Shh. They're coming back.
MARIA: My sister will be here with more tea presently. Would you like some more sherry, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Well, that’s very kind of you, Maria, but I won't, thank you.
MARIA: Eliza, what have you done?
ELIZA: Stupid, stupid Eliza. I dropped them, Maria. I dropped the lot! Look, spilled and smashed. No good, no good now.
MARIA: It’s all right. It doesn’t matter.
MEL: Here, let me help.
DOCTOR: What made you drop them? We heard something.
ELIZA: It was the noise, Maria. Those... those things are getting in.
DOCTOR: Things?
ELIZA: Getting in from outside. They’re coming in from the woods. They are coming into our house now. We must be on our guard.
MEL: What things, Eliza?
ELIZA: Ghostly ghosts.
MARIA: She hears things. The noises play havoc with her imagination.
DOCTOR: Ghosts? Are you sure, Eliza?
ELIZA: Oh yes. I heard them. Nasty things. Fading away things. Even with my poor eyes I can glimpse them, shimmering, silvery, at the corner of my vision, the little I have left to me.
MARIA: Calm down, my dear. Calm down. Come and sit down.
MEL: There’s no such thing as ghosts, Eliza. You’re safe.
MARIA: But there is. Here on this world there is... something. This last remaining shard of a world, this awful splinter.
MEL: Really?
DOCTOR: Awful splinter?
MARIA: Here, help me settle her on the sofa.
DOCTOR: One, two, three, hup. Ah. There, better now?
ELIZA: Much.
MEL: Tell us more, Maria, about the ghosts.
MARIA: The woods, out there, they are alive with ghosts, with macabre presences. We are safe here indoors, except lately my sister has been sensing them in here.
ELIZA: They are getting inside. They are all around us.
MARIA: Oh, it is of no interest to you. We mustn’t be side-tracked into talking about our fears and our woes.
MEL: Oh, we don’t mind, do we, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Of course not.
MEL: We’d like to help if we can.
MARIA: Another sherry, Doctor. Let us listen to Melanie. Melanie, will you tell us about your adventures in Time and Space?
MEL: Oh, really, it’s not just me
DOCTOR: Actually, I won’t have another drink, thank you. I think I'll pop back to the Tardis. I want to, well, check she’s safely locked up. I don’t want ghosts creeping around inside it.
ELIZA: Oh, ghosts inside.
MARIA: There, there, there. There, there, there.
MEL: (sotto) Do you really think they might get inside?
DOCTOR: Probably not, but I want to see if the Tardis has picked up any psionic energy emissions.
MEL: Psionic? But what about me?
DOCTOR: Oh, I think these two are harmless enough. (normal) So, you carry on, Mel. You stay here. Tell them about your travels.
MEL: All right, Doctor.
ELIZA: Stay, Doctor. Stay here by the fire.
DOCTOR: No, really, I need to stretch my legs.
MARIA: Oh, of course. You are our honoured guest. The companion of Melanie. You must come and go as you please.
DOCTOR: You're very kind.
MARIA: Dinner will be at six, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Splendid. Just enough time. Ladies.
ELIZA: More, Melanie. Tell us more.
MARIA: Yes, tell us all about your fabulous adventures.
DOCTOR: Let’s see what kind of energy emissions we’re getting. Ah. Most interesting. You’re out there, aren’t you. I can sense you. The Tardis can feel your presence. Make yourself known to me.
DOCTOR: So you are there. Almost intangible, almost invisible, but you are there. You’re trying to get through, you’re trying to communicate. Is it me you want? Are you trying to talk to me, hmm?
DOCTOR: Tell me, I'll listen. Talk to me. (silence) Oh, come back. What’s happened to you? Come back and talk to me! Ah, gone. Energy emissions have gone too. But it was definitely there.
DOCTOR: Ah. Really, I must say compliments to the chef, Maria. The food is excellent.
MEL: It really is.
MARIA: Daniel would have been so pleased to meet them, wouldn’t he, Eliza?
ELIZA: Oh yes. Yes, oh yes.
MARIA: He so wanted to be a traveller himself, you see. Why, he would have been flabbergasted by your tales of travelling the cosmos. The way you make it sound, it seems so easy. Skipping from world to world, time after time.
ELIZA: So easy. Too easy.
MEL: Well, it’s not as easy as all that. But tell me, who is Daniel?
ELIZA: Daniel is... Daniel is no more. Daniel was. He was once.
MARIA: Shush. Eliza, don’t upset yourself. Daniel was our brother, Melanie. He died many years ago. When we first came to this terrible land it was just the three of us. Like three shipwrecked sailors we were, washed up on the jagged reefs of this asteroid. We were only children. Just little children.
ELIZA: Daniel was our brother. He was younger than us, but he was our champion, our protector. He was, he was.
MEL: Oh, I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to pry
DOCTOR: Well, we all have our sad tales, don’t we.
MEL: Do you, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Oh, enough of this gloomy talk. What about this Wishing Beast, hmm? I’m fascinated by that.
ELIZA: Tomorrow. Tomorrow is the day for wishes.
MARIA: My sister is correct. Tomorrow all will become clear. You will receive your reward, Melanie.
MEL: Really, you know, I don’t actually need a reward. Honestly.
DOCTOR: Oh, don’t be so modest, Mel. Just look at the things you’ve faced up to since you’ve been in my company. Awful things.
MARIA: Eliza, do come and help me with dessert. Do forgive us, Melanie. We must go and tend to the dessert.
DOCTOR: Just desserts, eh?
MARIA: I’m sorry?
DOCTOR: Just a joke.
MARIA: Ah yes. You are very whimsical, Doctor. What a boon you must be to Melanie on her adventures. Come, sister.
DOCTOR: Oh. Well, am I a boon?
MEL: (laughing) Oh definitely, Doctor. Wait till you see the rooms they've given us. Mine is just spectacular. Real luxury.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure I want to stay the night here. Not after what happened when I went back to the Tardis.
MEL: Oh yes. Quick, tell me before they come back.
DOCTOR: I was haunted.
MEL: What? Doctor, are you sure?
DOCTOR: I was in the console room, and there was this tapping on the outer shell of the Tardis. And when I talked to it, it became louder, more frenetic.
MEL: Someone outside?
DOCTOR: The instruments gave only a partial reading, but there was something. Someone was there, someone not quite solid, someone not quite...
MEL: Not quite what?
DOCTOR: Not quite living.
MEL: Did you see them?
DOCTOR: They evaporated. Simply melted away.
MEL: Do you think whoever it was was following us in the woods?
DOCTOR: Perhaps. But there’s worse than that. The Tardis herself is somehow affected. Jammed.
MEL: Jammed?
DOCTOR: We couldn't take off now if we wanted to. Something has got into her.
MARIA: Here we are.
ELIZA: We are, we are. Here’s just desserts.
MEL: That’s magnificent!
DOCTOR: That must be the biggest trifle in the universe.
MARIA: You flatter us, Doctor.
DOCTOR: And you are spoiling us, my dear Maria.
MARIA: Will you let me propose a toast?
DOCTOR: Oh, yes.
MARIA: Blessings on our esteemed guests, and especially to Melanie, whose travels we have been hearing so much about.
ALL: To Melanie.
MARIA: Tomorrow you will receive your great reward, Melanie.
MEL: What was that?
DOCTOR: A door, I think.
ELIZA: Reward, reward. Tomorrow will be the day.
MARIA: Tomorrow we rise early and we ride out deep into the woods, in our carriage.
DOCTOR: There, again.
MEL: But can’t they hear it?
MARIA: Hear what, my dear?
DOCTOR: Doors slamming, crashes. Mel, you can hear it too, can’t you? Don’t tell me it’s just me.
MEL: I can. It’s
MARIA: Now, tomorrow we shall go searching for the Wishing Beast himself.
MEL: Excuse me, Maria, but those noises.
ELIZA: Noises, noises. It’s the noisy noises, Maria.
DOCTOR: More of your ghosts, Maria?
MARIA: Please ignore them. There’s nothing to see.
GHOST: We asked you to listen. We asked you to hear us. We didn’t want to cause a scene or make a fuss. Now you will listen to us.
MEL: I don't believe it. Ghosts!
ELIZA: Noisy ghosts. I don’t like them. Make them go away.
MARIA: Leave us! Be gone! Ignore them, everyone. Pay them no heed.
MEL: Oh my God, Doctor.
DOCTOR: It’s all right, Mel. Don’t panic.
MEL: But that was right beside me.
DOCTOR: Go on, Maria. Carry on with what you were saying.
MARIA: Thank you, Doctor. We will all ride in our carriage to the very depths of the woods, and there we will face the Wishing Beast together, and Melanie will tell him her dearest wish.
ELIZA: She will. She will ask for her dearest wish.
MEL: I’m not even sure what that is.
DOCTOR: And then, Maria?
MARIA: And then, naturally, he will grant it.
DOCTOR: How? Why?
MARIA: You will see, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Sounds suspiciously like magic to me. And magic, like ghosts, may appear to be inexplicable, but they are only unexplained. And at the moment all this looks like a pretty poor display of cheap theatrics.
MEL: I think you spoke too soon, Doctor. Look at that thing. It’s horrible.
DOCTOR: How are you doing this, Maria? Is it you doing this?
ELIZA: Take it away. Take it.
MARIA: It has nothing to do with us, Doctor. These things come and go at will.
GHOST: Please, now we have your attention. Please, you must, you have to listen to us. Hard to cut through... psychic interference. The sisters won’t let us talk with you. We want to help
DOCTOR: What's it saying?
MARIA: Be gone. Leave us!
ELIZA: Be gone! Be gone! Be gone!
DOCTOR: Quiet! Let us hear.
GHOST: Doctor, Mel, listen to me. Flee from here. The sisters, they will be the death of all of us!

elements.text: [Part Two]
How very interesting.
I’m not having this.
Can I fetch it, Maria? Can I fetch it out of the cosy cupboard? Cosy cupboard under the stairs.
You do that, Eliza dear.
What’s she doing now?
Never mind her, Mel. Phantasm, spirit, soectre, banshee, whatever you are, what is it you want?
Please, they are going to get rid of me. You must listen before they send me away.
We are listening. Tell us.
Bah, foul spirit, leave this place. Be gone.
No, let him speak.
Have you done it, Eliza? Do you have it ready?
Tell us. Why should we flee the sisters? What’s happening here?
They will destroy me. I must go.
Eliza, quickly! Bring that thing here at once!
I have done it, Maria. Here it is.
Good. Now give it to me.
A vacuum cleaner?
Scourge of all ghostly nasties.
Vacuum cleaner starts up.
Be gone! Avaunt! Have away with ye, demon.
What the...?
Please. No. There’s hardly anything of me left in this world. Please. Ah!
Long, drawn-out, fading cry. Vacuum turned off.
Unbelievable.
Unforgivable! That’s no ordinary vacuum, is it, ladies.
It’s mine. Hands off!
As I thought. There’s a proton filter here.
Which means?
Which means
It sucks up spooky nasties.
It destabilises particles at the molecular level.
Which means?
That ghost had a physical presence. A slight one, I'll grant you, but
Which means turn it up to max and it can suck the life out of even you!
Vacuum on.
Careful!
Eliza dear, let’s not get excited. (vacuum off) Why don’t you pop the vacuum cleaner back under the
stairs?
Of course. Of course.
Door opens and closes.
You sucked the ghost up? Where is he?
Where all the old rubbish goes, I’m afraid. Oh dear, that’s the trifle on the floor.
You should have let him be.
He was very dangerous, Doctor.
To whom?
He was warning us against going to the Wishing Beast.
Of course he was. Envy. Who wouldn’t be envious, Mel? Who wouldn’t be jealous of what you’ve got coming to you tomorrow?
How’s your room?
Smaller on the inside. I think the cupboard under the stairs is bigger. How’s your luxury?
Somehow I didn’t notice. How are we going to get out of here?
We have to find out what’s going on, then perhaps we can undo whatever it is that’s jamming the Tardis. But one thing’s for sure. I don’t trust those sisters one inch.
Me neither. But I think you should take another look at the Tardis and see if you can fix it.
What, leave you here? I can’t do that.
At least they’re falling over themselves to be nice to me. I'll be all right. And they'll be happy as long as I’m here to be taken to their precious Wishing Beast in the morning.
I can’t let you face whatever that is on your own.
I won’t argue with that. Just make sure you’re back here by morning.
You're not scared?
Scared? Course I’m scared. But we’ve got to get to the bottom of this, haven’t we, or we’re stuck here.
Hmm. And I have to admit that I’m not altogether comfortable with taking another walk in that haunted forest. So, let’s both be brave, shall we?
Well, we can at least try.
All right. And you should try to get some sleep. I’ve a feeling we'll need our wits about us in the morning.
No point asking if you’ll get any sleep, I suppose.
Mmm. Think cat, not tortoise. And cats have all their best adventures at night.
The owl hoots, the Doctor is humming. Whoosh!

Hello? Who is that? It’s you again, isn’t it? Look, I know you’re following me. You might as well step out into the moonlight where I can see you. I am not budging from this spot till you show yourself. I don’t scare easily, you know.
Doctor.
Decided to show yourself, have you?
Doctor, we don’t have much time. The Applewhite sisters are abed. They are no danger to us for now until morning. I have this night to tell you what is going on here.
I’m glad someone is going to. Who are you? And keep still, will you? I can hardly focus on you.

I’m sorry about that. I'll try to fix my form a little more. But I am mostly insubstantial, Doctor. I am hardly here. My essence has been ripped away from me, and I am to all intents and purposes a phantom.
A phantom, indeed. And do you have a name?
Mildew.
How charming. And how’d you know who I am? I find it rather disconcerting, phantoms knowing all about me.
I have been watching you since you arrived here. I have been at your elbow, watching, hoping.
Hoping for what?
I think you can help us, all of us living here. Those of us who have suffered at the gnarled and wicked hands of those sisters.
Why should I believe you? The sisters seem to think you’re the wicked one.
Come with me. Please.
Where to? Further and deeper into this ghastly forest, I suppose. And what will I find there?
My people. More like me. Please, come.
Very well. Show me, then, Mildew. I’ll just have to trust you, won't I?
Maria. Maria, wake up. Oh please, my dearest sister. Sister, you must wake up.
Oh, Eliza, what is it? I’m old, I need my rest. Tomorrow will be arduous. You know what we need to do.
But I can’t sleep. I can’t get myself asleep, Maria.
Go back to bed.
May I come in with you?
Dear, you’re a child still, aren’t you.
That Doctor. I like him.
Mmm, I thought you might.
He’s gone, you know. Went out. Ever so careful, so no one would hear.
Did he really? Well, won’t get far. Mel didn’t go with him, did she? You’d have told me if Mel had gone, wouldn’t you, dear?
Oh, of course, of course, Maria.
He returned to his miraculous Tardis, of course, but he can’t take it anywhere.
Tomorrow we will see our Beast. We will see him again.
We will, my dear.
I love seeing him. I love him.
So you should. And so you should.
The Wishing Beast.
Shh. You mustn’t call him that really. Others do. To them he is a beast, but not to us. Not to us.
So, this is where you live?
This is our home, Doctor. Our village, hidden away deep inside the wintry woods.
How many of you are there?
Fewer than a hundred. The numbers fluctuate, depending.
Are all of you like this? Reduced to living wild in ruins like this?

We can't taste or touch or feel much at all. Some of us can concentrate ourselves and become manifest and corporeal for small spans of time. The cold doesn’t affect us. We can’t ingest anything nor have any need to. We can’t even lie down without sinking into the earth.
I’ve often wondered about that. How would ghosts even walk on the ground? Why wouldn't they just drop through?
But we do.
That much is clear to me, Mildew, but little else at the moment.
It takes an immense and continuous effort of will to hover above the ground and manifest ourselves so that the likes of you, the corporeal ones, can see us.
It’s quite staggering. I feel as if I’m dreaming and sleep-walking. I am honoured to be brought here.
My people are fascinated by you, Doctor. They see so very little colour in their lives. Colour is one of the many sensations they’ve had taken away from them.
Well, I’m happy to oblige. I think.
Sit here, Doctor. Let them pass by you. Let them see you.
Here? Er, hello, everyone.
2: My brother, you must have seen him.
I’m sorry?

2: My brother got into the bad house. He was brave. The bravest of all of us. He tried to warn you and your friend to beware the sisters. He does not respond now when I shout. Where is he now, my brother?
I’m afraid... I’m sorry, but they got rid of him. I think... I think they destroyed him.
2: Noooooo!
Spectral wailing.
They mourn the loss of one of us.
I’m so sorry about the loss of his brother. There was nothing I could do.
We understand, Doctor.
So, how do you all come to be here?
We were lured by those sisters.
Really. Like the victims of the sirens.
With the promise of... oh, it sounds so foolish now. The promise of our
Dearest wish?
To be granted by the fabled Wishing Beast.
I see.
They flattered everyone of us. We were the brave travellers, the heroic explorers.
And when you got here?
We were all received with open arms by the sisters, with a rapturous welcome at their mansion. We were fed and cared for. We were told we were heroes. Then we were taken to see the Wishing Beast.
And?

And then it made us what you see now. It eats us, Doctor. That is why we are brought here. It is why you and your friend are here. Fodder for the creature that says it grants wishes. What will you do, Doctor?
I’m going to help you. We’re going to do something about this.
It is almost morning, Doctor. The sisters will be riding out soon to find the Wishing Beast.
Mel! They’re taking Mel.
Wait, Doctor.
I must return to their house.
They will come here first, to our village.
Here? Why?
Good morning, Melanie dear. Come, you must eat something before our journey begins.
Oh, I'll have a glass of fruit juice. Nothing else, thanks. I feel a bit nervous, to be honest.
Nervous. Nervous. I am always nervous when we go and see him. He is so changed.
Shush, Eliza. We don’t want to worry Melanie. Just think. The stables, Eliza. You love the horses. And the carriage. You love our little jaunts out from the stables.
Who is so changed?
For the better, we think. He is a better creature. A magical thing.
But
Our brother.
You told me he was dead.
It seems easier to tell our story that way sometimes, even though it isn’t actually true. But people don’t always believe the truth when you tell them, do they?
Daniel changed, when we came here. He became something else. His body, everything. He got powers.

As I told you, Melanie, we were only children. We were washed up here on this shattered asteroid in the wreckage of a Space cruiser many years ago. Our parents, everyone we knew, had been killed in the attack. And we were all that was left.
And Daniel was hurt. Badly hurt.
And the space radiation or whatever it was acted on his tissues and his injuries. I don’t understand science, but our Daniel changed.
Oh, my God. You mean he mutated?
Oh, is that the word? I don’t know.
I changed too. Tell her, Maria. My dark glasses. Behind these lenses I am a changed being too.

Yes, Eliza, you changed too, and that is why you are... different. But Daniel changed by far the most. He grew a dragon-like skin, a pelt of fine-spun scaly gold. He grew extra limbs. His eyes grew reptilian and shrewd. He moved away from us. He couldn’t live with his sisters any more. He withdrew into the forest to nurse his horrendous wounds and alterations, and to try out his new-found powers.
Oh, my God.
I thought it best you knew before we rode out this morning.
He is our brother. Our little one.
Tell me about the sisters, Mildew.
They take us away.
They come for us often.
Tell the Doctor about what they do to us.
They come here for tribute. They feed a handful of us ghosts to the Wishing Beast as appetisers before the main sacrifice. It happens each time they go to meet it.
Oh, that’s horrible! But you’ve already been absorbed once. He turned you into phantoms, you said. Well, how can he consume you again?
There are layers and layers to a living essence, Doctor. The Wishing Beast is clever. He rarely eats a soul all in one go. He strips us away skin by skin.
Ah. The Wishing Beast was originally Daniel Applewhite, wasn’t he? That’s why the sisters are so preoccupied with him
You are right, so right. You guessed right.
They tend to him, feed him. He’s still their little brother, whatever he has become.
Er, have either of you seen the Doctor this morning?
Come along, Mel. It’s time we were going deep into the woods.
But
He’s left you, Melanie. The Doctor has left you to your dearest wish.
I have stowed our weapon safely aboard, Eliza.
And the rugs for our knees. The air is so sharp this morning.
Everything is here. Climb aboard.
Why do we need weapons, Maria?
The woods are thick with evil spirits. You observed that yourself. We are three women travelling into a very dangerous region.
Er, I really think we should wait for the Doctor.
No. He has abandoned you. He’s run away. He’s gone.
No, he wouldn't do that. Can we go to the Tardis first?
Dawn is here. What happens in daylight, Mildew?
We are still here. A little paler perhaps, less tangible maybe, but we are here nevertheless.
2: We are always here.
You are back, my friend.
2: I’ve been thinking. He didn’t do anything to save my brother back at the mansion.
Your brother knew the risks. Haunting the Applewhite sisters, he was taking his life into his hands.
2: As I see it, this fellow owes us.
Believe me please. I’m appalled at what happened to your brother, and I will do what I can.
2: Not good enough. Easy to promise when you're alive, when you're in the land of the living, but what are you going to do, eh?
What do you want me to do? Tell me what you want me to do.
Knocking.
Doctor? Come on, wake up. You said you weren’t a tortoise. You always say you don’t need sleep. Doctor?
Melanie dear, do hurry.
No sign of him.
We must move, Melanie. We need to get to the place.
Oh, forget the Doctor. Forget him.
But he wouldn’t just
Headstrong, isn’t he? Probably jealous that he won’t get his dearest wish. Not like you, Melanie. Melanie the hero.
Perhaps... perhaps he’s gone on ahead.
That’s it, my dear. The silly man has set off early. He wants to get there before us.
I suppose he might have. It is the kind of thing he might do.
Come along, my dear. Back aboard our carriage.
2: We could make him, Mildew. We could force him, couldn’t we? To take the pressure off us for a while.
What are you talking about? Tell me.
2: Feed him to the Wishing Beast.
What?
2: We don’t know him. What does he matter to us? He’s no one to us.
The Doctor is going to help us.
Any way I can.
2: This will be the best way. Feed him to the Wishing Beast.
(sigh) Then perhaps you're right.
What’s going on? Are we there already?
We need to stop. We need to stop in the village. For supplies.
Bring the vacuum, Eliza.
My vacuum. My dear vacuum cleaner.
What village? All I can see is a kind of mist.
Melanie. Melanie.
Look harder, Melanie. Can’t you see them? Stare into the mist.
What? I can hear them.
Please help us. Help us defend ourselves.
Hello?
Shades and spirits, attend to me.
2: You killed him. You sucked away his essence.
Leave us. Leave us be, you harlots, you witches.
I can see them, hundreds of them.
Yes. See their horrible spectral faces and fingers, their haunted eyes. Look on them, Melanie. Aren’t these the creatures that scared you in the wood?
Tell them to go. Melanie, please.
Why have we come here? Maria? Eliza?
Tributes. We gather tributes to our poor brave brother. It's what we always do.
Eliza, get the vacuum going.
2: Don’t let them. Help us, please!
Stir and stir around. Suck them up, suck them up.
No! Melanie, help us! Listen to us!
Listen to me, half-people of Ghost Town. Give up a handful of your pathetic number and I will leave the rest of you alone, for now. Just give us a few tributes for us to take to the Wishing Beast.
You will leave nothing left of us.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Get away from me. You two make me sick. I can’t believe that I listened to what you were saying, even for a second.
Daniel, Daniel, don’t come too close, my dear. Our darling boy.
We are your sisters, your loving sisters. And we bring you souls. Fresh souls again.
Fresh from your ghastly vacuum cleaner, I suppose.
Let me just switch it from suck to blow, and suck them up, Daniel dear. All these poor pathetic wraiths.
It’s horrible! I can’t let you do this. Give me that thing.
Keep back, Doctor. Eliza.
Careful, Doctor. Eliza can shoot laser beams from her eyes.
But can’t you see this is wrong?
One step closer, Doctor, and Eliza will fry Mel to a cinder.
Burn, burn, burn!
It seems that we are powerless to intervene in this disgusting spectacle.
Those poor souls, being sucked up by that creature. It seems incredible that it’s really their brother.
Yes. Poor boy.
Poor, Doctor? You look at that monstrosity feeding on the souls of my fellow villagers and feel pity for him?
Ah, Mel, this transparent colleague of mine, his name is Mildew. He’s been filling me in on some of the background here
I cannot stand here, Doctor, while they do this. Look at them.
Our darling Daniel. Eat well, my dear.
Suck that essence. Draw out the goodness. Goodness, oh.
It’s gone too far. I've seen enough of this. Sisters!
What are you going to do, Doctor?
Ah, the brave Doctor steps forward. Do you want a taste of our vacuum too, Doctor?
Doctor, tell me what you’re going to do.
The only thing I can do, Mel.
Melanie, you must come here. Tell the Beast your dearest wish.
The sisters laugh.
Not on yout life.
No, she wont. But I will. It has to be me.
Doctor, no!
I think he is right, Mel. The Wishing Beast won't go unless he
Unless he is appeased, and he still looks pretty hungry to me.
He’s hungry. He wants more and more.
And I suspect a Time Lord from Gallifrey would go some way to filling up that rumbling void in his belly, eh?
A Lord of Time. Oh!
How wonderful. And we thought he was just a companion, didn’t we, Eliza? We thought Mel was the one.
Just take me to the Wishing Beast. I’m sure I have more than enough essence to satisfy him fora while.
Oh, more than enough, Doctor.
More than, much more than.
And if I give myself up now, will you promise me, will you give me your oath, that there will be no more killings?
No more lurings, murders? Oh, impossible. We love it. We love what we do.
Just think of it, Eliza. A Lord of Time giving all his lives for the sake of our brother! We must honour his conditions.
Marvellous. Marvellous! A Time Lord..
No, Doctor, I’m not letting you do this.
Mel, don’t interfere.
Is this one of your plans? One of your fantastic wheezes? You’ve got something up your sleeve, haven't you?
Perhaps. I’m going now.
You can't.
Let him do it, Mel.
Oh, shut up, you. You and all the other ghosts, well, you’re already dead. The Doctor isn't.

Mel, these ghosts, they’ve a physical presence. Against all odds they’re clinging on to life, clinging on to this ghastly benighted rock. That doesn’t make them lesser beings. It means they need protecting. And if my death is what it takes to protect them, even for a little while longer
Oh, spare us the noble sacrifice speech. Your dying won’t change things here.
You must listen, Mel. When I’m gone, the sisters will be after the Tardis. They will try to take it. It must not fall into their hands, do you hear me?
Oh Doctor, you really mean it, don’t you? This is really goodbye.
I think it might well be, Mel.
Doctor, ready yourself.
I have said my goodbyes.
Walk right up to him, Doctor. Walk up to his open jaws, close your eyes. You will feel yourself draining away rather gently, rather peacefully. There, there. Your life has been long and hectic.
A busy life. So busy, busy. You can rest now, in the arms of the Beast.
Yes. I can go now.
Doctor, please! There must be another way.
She cannot help you now. Be content, Doctor. Your friends are safe with us. Let yourself fade and trickle away, and you will wake up... elsewhere.
No! Doctor!
There. He is gone. He’s gone, in one huge gollop.
Look at them out there. What a drama. There’s always a drama.
Who's that? Oh, can’t you let me die in peace?
Now, you didn’t really think you’d be dead, did you, Doctor?
Oh, what are you talking about? And where are we?
Inside the Wishing Beast. Inside me, so to speak.
Are you Daniel Applewhite?
My reputation precedes me.
Are you proud of that?

Would that be such a bad thing?
You tell me, Daniel.

Try me.
Over three centuries. There, does that shock you?

Welcome to the Wishing Beast.
You’re a kind of hybrid. A compound being, made up of the original Daniel Applewhite and

I wanted to meet you. And lets just say I had a hunch you wanted to meet me.
Astute.

Ah.
Mel is crying.
